videos.title: The Crazy Physics of Jet Engines
videos.description:
This is one of the most powerful jet engines in the world, and it runs at temperatures more than 250 degrees celsius hotter than the melting point of the materials that make it up.

So why doesn't it melt?

Notes

*When we show the Stern Gerlach experiment we‚Äôve chosen to flip the polarity of the machine when measuring a positron. This is because both its spin and charge should oppose the electron‚Äôs. This would mean both would bend in the same direction! We‚Äôre interested in seeing the difference in the spins so we flip the machine to make this clearer. 

**We show curved spacetime using Flamm‚Äôs Parabaloid, which we discovered is controversial, more notes on that here - https://ve42.co/HBDFlamm

videos.title: What is this strange pattern down the east coast of America?
videos.description:
There is this strange pattern of bodies of water all down the east coast of America and most of them point northwest. 

They're called Carolina Bays as they're found predominantly in the Carolina states, and they're home to some crazy wildlife. 

But how did they form?

videos.title: Can you swim in shade balls?
videos.description:
I bought 10,000 shade balls and tried to swim in them. 

They appear to act like a non-Newtonian fluid: rigid under high shear stress, but they flow like a liquid under low shear.

videos.title: Testing the US Military‚Äôs worst idea
videos.description:
Rods from God.

This is the nickname for a theoretical space weapon, in which large rods of tungsten would be dropped onto Earth based targets. 

The idea behind this weapon is that the projectiles would build up enough speed, and thus kinetic energy, which would cause bomb-like destruction on the ground below. 

The concept was devised during the Cold War but has faced heavy criticism both logistically and scientifically.

However, it has certainly made its mark on science fiction, both appearing in and being referenced across many media, from TV to video games.

But could it work in practice? 

We tested to find out.

videos.title: How a Student's Question Saved This NYC Skyscraper
videos.description:
How a single phone call from a student helped uncover a flaw that nearly toppled Citicorp. Get an exclusive 15% discount on Saily data plans! Use code veritasium at checkout. Download Saily app or go to https://saily.com/veritasium 

If you‚Äôre looking for a molecular modeling kit, try Snatoms, a kit I invented where the atoms snap together magnetically - https://ve42.co/SnatomsV 

Correction: From construction images of Citicorp, sharp-eyed viewers might see that the mid-V columns are still there. Those columns help prevent buckling of the diagonal and the weight of people on the floor above, but do not take the majority of the gravity load. So we left them out of our diagram to clearly explain the load paths. See page 70 of this source for more details - https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ODFo66-_V7Y9vKANbj53mQ0z20RZ2Uai/view
